Hourly Clean Energy Cost Optimizer

Procurement Strategy & Cost Optimization Analysis

Investing in clean firm power today is the single
most important step toward deep decarbonization

Our analysis of 8,760 hours across five U.S. power markets reveals that cheap renewables alone cannot achieve high hourly matching targets. Beyond 90% matching, the cost curve inflects sharply and the resource mix pivots toward firm, dispatchable clean generation. Organizations that invest only in wind and solar today will face steep costs and stranded procurement when they pursue deeper decarbonization. The time to secure clean firm power is now — before you need it.

Methodology & Technical Reference

This analysis uses a co-optimization approach that simultaneously minimizes cost while achieving target hourly matching thresholds. Resource mixes, procurement levels, and storage dispatch are jointly optimized using a three-phase refinement process with numpy-accelerated scoring.

View Full Methodology & Data Sources →

Scroll down to explore the full story of hourly matching — from the challenge of precision to the cost of that final 1%

↓

The Bottom Line: Plan Ahead for Clean Firm Power

Your resource mix today determines your decarbonization costs tomorrow

This analysis reveals a fundamental strategic insight: the resource mix that is cheapest at lower matching targets is not the resource mix you need at higher ones. As hourly matching ambitions rise from 75% to 90% to 99%, the optimal portfolio undergoes a dramatic transformation — from wind and solar dominance to an increasingly critical role for clean firm power (nuclear, geothermal, and CCS-equipped gas).

75% Matching

Wind and solar dominate. Cheap renewables cover most hours cost-effectively. The easy path.

90% — The Decision Point

Cost-per-point doubles. The mix pivots toward clean firm. Decisions made here lock in your trajectory.

99%+ — The Cliff

The last 1% costs as much as the entire 75–99% journey combined. Only firm generation survives here.

The overbuilding trap: Overinvesting in wind and solar may appear cost-effective in the short term, but it creates a costly problem at higher matching targets. Excess intermittent capacity leads to massive curtailment — energy you pay for but cannot use. At 99% matching, curtailment can exceed 40% of total procurement. Every dollar spent on capacity that will later be curtailed is a dollar not invested in the clean firm resources you will inevitably need.

Short-duration storage alone won’t close the gap. In this analysis (4-hour Li-ion), battery deployment remains near zero below 95% matching. Four-hour storage can shift solar surplus to evenings but struggles with multi-day wind droughts and long winter nights. Longer-duration storage technologies (iron-air, compressed air, hydrogen) may expand storage’s role significantly — but firm, dispatchable generation will remain essential for the hardest hours regardless.

Existing clean firm is irreplaceable at any cost. PJM (32% nuclear), NEISO (24%), and NYISO (18%) benefit enormously from already-built nuclear fleets that deliver clean baseload at wholesale prices. Losing these assets to economic shutdown — as nearly happened in the 2010s — would add $5–18/MWh to every matching target. These plants should be valued not by today’s wholesale price, but by the cost of replacing them.

Organizations serious about deep decarbonization should secure and procure clean firm power early — whether through nuclear PPAs, geothermal contracts, or investments in CCS-ready gas infrastructure. Waiting to address the firm power gap until you are already targeting 95%+ matching means competing for scarce resources in a seller’s market, at significantly higher costs.

Plan for where you’re going, not just where you are today.
The Challenge

From Annual Matching to Hourly: The Cost of Precision

Proposed GHG Protocol revisions will require matching clean energy supply to demand every single hour — not just annually. This fundamentally changes procurement economics.

8,760
Hours per year
5
ISO regions
2x
Cost escalation at 100%

When every hour counts, intermittency becomes a critical cost driver. The pathway from 75% to 100% hourly matching reveals an exponential cost curve that procurement teams need to plan for.

Key Insight

The Exponential Cost of Perfection

This chart shows the blended cost per MWh for each hourly matching target, averaged across all five ISO regions. The relationship is non-linear — the last few percentage points of matching cost dramatically more than the first.

Accessible

75% Matching: The Low-Hanging Fruit

Achieving 75% hourly matching is surprisingly affordable. With just 80–90% procurement and a wind/solar-heavy mix, buyers can match three-quarters of their demand hourly for a modest premium above wholesale rates.

Avg Cost: ~$47/MWh — within reach for most corporate buyers
Decision Point

90% Matching: The True Inflection

At 90%, the cost-per-percentage-point doubles compared to 85%. This is the real decision point: beyond here, clean firm power becomes essential and the cost curve steepens dramatically. Procurement rises to 100–120% and the mix begins its pivot toward dispatchable resources.

Avg Cost: ~$55/MWh — costs begin accelerating sharply
Premium

99–100%: The Steep Climb

The final percentage points are the most expensive. Costs can exceed $75–$90/MWh — 1.5–2x the cost of 75% matching. These last unmatched hours are extreme weather events and overnight wind droughts that only firm generation can reliably cover.

Avg Cost: ~$77/MWh — extreme weather hours drive the final premium
Resource Strategy

How the Optimal Mix Evolves

At lower matching targets, solar and wind dominate because they are the cheapest per MWh. As matching targets rise, the mix shifts toward clean firm power (nuclear, geothermal) — the only resources that generate reliably regardless of weather.

Regional Variation: Wind-rich ERCOT sustains wind-heavy mixes to 95%+, while PJM and NEISO require a pivot to nuclear/clean firm at lower thresholds.
The Tradeoff

Surplus Procurement & Curtailment

Every percentage point of additional hourly matching requires more procurement — energy generated but never consumed. This curtailed energy has real cost: capacity built and paid for, even though it serves no direct load.

75%
~5%
curtailed
85%
~15%
curtailed
95%
~25%
curtailed
99%
~40%
curtailed
100%
~55%
curtailed

Solar is curtailed first, then wind, then hydro, with clean firm curtailed last. At high matching targets, nearly half of all procured energy goes unused — roughly doubling the effective cost per useful MWh. This curtailment penalty is the fundamental constraint on achieving deep decarbonization with intermittent resources alone.

Reliability

Residual Backup Capacity

Even at 99% hourly matching, most regions still require 20–60% of peak demand in backup capacity for the worst single hour. Traditional firm generation or demand response must remain available for extreme events.

72%
CAISO
80%
ERCOT
60%
PJM
45%
NYISO
38%
NEISO

Clean coverage of peak demand at 99% hourly matching (higher = less backup needed)

The Trilemma

From Two Dimensions to Three

For decades, energy planning balanced reliability and affordability. Hourly matching adds a third dimension: clean.

At 75% matching, affordability dominates — cheap renewables suffice. By 95%, reliability forces the mix toward costlier firm generation. At 99%+, all three dimensions are stressed, requiring the full toolkit: renewables, firm generation, and dispatchable low-carbon sources. There is no single right threshold — each organization must find its own balance.

Transition Pathway

The Role of Efficient Gas & Carbon Capture

What fills the gap when renewables can’t? Efficient natural gas CCGTs serve as a transition fuel today — and a CCS-ready platform for clean firm power tomorrow.

Efficient CCGT
60%+ efficiency, fast-ramping, ~350 kg CO₂/MWh (half of coal). Covers the hours renewables cannot.
~350 kg
CO₂/MWh (vs 900+ for coal)
CCGT + CCS
Retrofit with 90%+ CO₂ capture. Same plant transitions from backup to dispatchable clean firm power.
85-95%
CO₂ capture rate potential

Modern CCS-ready CCGTs avoid stranded assets: the backup infrastructure built for 95% matching today delivers dispatchable clean power at 99%+ matching tomorrow. The hardest hours — winter evenings with no sun and calm wind — are precisely where dispatchable generation provides the greatest value.

Critical Asset

Existing Nuclear & Geothermal: The Foundation We Can’t Afford to Lose

Existing nuclear and geothermal plants are the most cost-effective clean firm generation we have. Unlike new-build options, they carry no upfront capital expenditure or steep financing costs. Keeping these resources online is not just beneficial — it is essential to achieving deep decarbonization.

Yet cheap natural gas and subsidized renewables continue to pressure these plants economically — the same dynamic that drove several nuclear shutdowns in the 2010s. Once retired, a plant cannot economically restart, and replacing it requires new-build at 2–3x the cost. Our model quantifies this directly:

Cost Impact of Losing Existing Clean Firm Resources

If existing nuclear/geothermal had to be replaced with new-build at $90/MWh
PJM 32.1% existing clean firm
+$18/MWh (+31–39%)
Largest nuclear fleet. At 90% matching, costs jump from $59 to $77/MWh. The existing fleet saves more per MWh than any other single intervention.
NEISO 23.8% existing clean firm
+$12/MWh (+17–21%)
Millstone and Seabrook anchor New England’s clean firm supply. Losing them would push 90% matching costs above $80/MWh.
NYISO 18.4% existing clean firm
+$9/MWh (+14–16%)
Indian Point’s closure already demonstrated the cost. The remaining fleet is critical to any affordable path beyond 90%.
ERCOT & CAISO 8–9% existing clean firm
+$5/MWh (+9–15%)
Smaller fleets but still significant. Even 8% of baseload clean firm at wholesale prices saves $5/MWh across every matching target.

These assets should be valued not by today’s wholesale price, but by the cost of replacing them: $90/MWh new-build vs. $27–42/MWh wholesale. Where existing plants provide the foundation, CCS-retrofitted gas plants can build on it. Current estimates: $70–100/MWh LCOE before incentives.

$85/ton
45Q tax credit per ton of CO₂ captured (post-OBBBA)
$15–25
$/MWh effective 45Q offset for CCGT+CCS at 90% capture
$55–80
$/MWh net LCOE after 45Q credit (competitive with new nuclear)

With 45Q credits, net LCOE falls to $55–80/MWh — competitive with new nuclear. To maximize captured CO₂ and 45Q value, CCS plants would run at high capacity factors resembling baseload dispatch: exactly the role the grid needs filled.

Protect What You Have, Build What You Need: Existing nuclear and geothermal provide irreplaceable clean firm generation at a fraction of new-build cost. Losing these assets to economic pressure would increase decarbonization costs by $5–18/MWh depending on region — a penalty that compounds at every matching target. Meanwhile, CCS retrofits on existing gas infrastructure offer the most viable near-term pathway to add new clean firm capacity at costs competitive with new nuclear, especially with 45Q incentives driving baseload-like operation.
Important Context

What This Analysis Does Not Capture

This optimization models energy procurement and resource costs but does not include transmission, distribution, or interconnection costs. In practice, these costs can materially change the economics — and may strengthen or weaken the case for specific resource types depending on geography and grid constraints.

Transmission & Distribution Considerations

$15–40+
$/MWh added cost for new long-distance transmission (HVDC, regional backbone)
5–10+ yrs
Typical timeline for major transmission permitting and construction
2,000+ GW
of generation stuck in U.S. interconnection queues (mostly wind & solar)

Remote renewables face the largest T&D burden: $15–40+/MWh for new transmission from resource-rich areas to load centers, plus 5+ year interconnection queue delays. This hidden cost narrows renewables’ apparent LCOE advantage over firm resources sited closer to demand.

Existing nuclear and CCS-retrofit gas plants are already interconnected at high-voltage nodes near population centers — no new transmission investment or queue delays required. CCS does add CO₂ pipeline infrastructure, but avoids the electrical interconnection bottleneck. Longer-duration storage could reduce transmission needs by siting near load centers, an area where future T&D-inclusive analysis may shift the optimal mix.

Net Impact: Including transmission and interconnection costs would likely strengthen the case for existing nuclear (already connected), increase the true delivered cost of remote renewables, and add complexity to CCS deployment (CO₂ pipelines). Our cost estimates for wind and solar should be considered optimistic relative to fully delivered costs in many regions.
Analysis based on 8,760-hour dispatch modeling • Storage: 4h duration, 85% round-trip efficiency • CO₂ accounting follows hourly matching protocol
